Thanks for the ideas, John.

I will definitely experiment with random noise at some
point, whether it's within the network or introduced
at the inputs.  I'm currently using a continuous-time
recurrent neural network (CTRNN) with "leaky
integrator neurons", which has the property of
producing smooth rhythmic outputs.  This might already
be capable of doing what your oscillation nodes idea
would do.  I'll keep it in mind, though.  Maybe an
oscillation node could be a cheaper representation of
a whole sub-network of recurrent connections.

Tyler

--- John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@...> wrote:
> On this subject, I had an idea that you may or may
> not want to consider...
> 
> There is a 'bias' input node that helps all the
> others alter their behavior 
> by learning an appropriate weight.  What if there
> were other such 'utility' 
> inputs.
> 
> For example, a random input node.  Either assign it
> a random value at the 
> beginning of an each activation, or have its value
> change every time it is 
> read.  The network will, of course, evolve to
> minimize the weights to the 
> random node.  But the presence of random
> fluctuations in the environment 
> will force it to adopt a different strategy of
> execution.
> 
> Without it, the network could (and is likely to)
> evolve into something that 
> just replays a set of motions that happen to work
> while in the fitness 
> evaluation environment.  Change any factor, and it
> may completely fail.  You 
> could get around that by testing it in a variety of
> environments.  Then, an 
> already lengthy fitness evaluation cycle is
> magnified many times over.  But 
> forcing it to evolve in the presence of noise within
> its own system will 
> force it to adopt a more adaptive approach to
> accomplishing what it is being 
> asked to do.  You will get a network that can
> accomodate obstacles or rough 
> terrain without necessarily having to test for it
> from the beginning.  Not 
> only that, but the presence of minor variations,
> imperfections within the 
> gait, may make the result look more natural.
> 
> Another idea is 'oscillation' nodes.  An input node
> that returns sin(x+=n) 
> where n controls how fast it oscillates.  Or a
> hidden node that does the 
> same thing, but where the value of 'n' is based on
> the inputs, so it can 
> speed up or slow down depending on what the rest of
> the network indicates.  
> The oscillating input will give it a sense of time. 
> The oscillating hidden 
> node will give it the ability to go through cycles,
> but adapt those cycles 
> as needed, and in a way that is probably more
> adaptive than a recurrent 
> network could accomplish.  It might well accomplish
> more with less topology 
> with the availability of such structures.
> 
> Such variations would be almost trivial to
> implement, and could potentially 
> have far-reaching influence on the resulting
> evolutions.  Of course, the 
> only way to know if the benefits outweight the
> increase in search-space is 
> to actually implement them and see.  I would be
> willing to bet that the 
> random input would be worth the effort for you.
> 
> -- John
